Award.AwardTitle: Computing Professionals Creating Inclusive STEM Communities

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Cultivating Ensembles in Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics (STEM) Education and Research is a professional development conference that brings together people in STEM to learn from one another's practices in science communication, diversity and inclusion, outreach, creativity, and performance. Grown from efforts to develop creativity in computing, this biennial meeting integrates the arts and sciences to create compelling learning for students and engage people in developing an inclusive, inter- and trans-disciplinary STEM culture. The proposed initiative makes use of an established community to further the understanding and innovation that Arts and STEM integration can foster in broadening participation and workforce development.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Cultivating Ensembles conference (formerly branded as CESTEMER) brings together individuals with different sensibilities and interests in science, technology, engineering, mathematics, and medicine (STEM) to celebrate the interwoven nature of sciences, technologies, humanities, and arts as human activities. Together we co-create the conditions in which we learn from, leverage, and share our diverse experiences.  We aim to build an inclusive community that answers the question, If all the world''s a stage, who are our players and what are we making?

Dr. Jaime E. Martinez, in collaboration with a conference organizing committee, hosted the Cultivating Ensembles in STEM Education and Research (CESTEMER) conference at the New York Institute of Technology in New York City, June 19-20th 2019 during the funding period of the conference grant (June 2019 - December 2020). 

CESTEMER 2019 showcased 48 interactive sessions. The conference included 100 attendees and presenters. Conference funds were used to support 23 early-career scholars to travel, participate, and present at the conference. The demographic composition of the early-career scholars was as follows: 86% Female, 56% African-American or bi-racial, 7% Hispanic, 21% White, with 14% preferring not to respond. They represented the following fields; physics, biology/biotechnology, mathematics education, science education, science communication, mental health, informal science education, teacher education, and arts. The conference roughly doubled attendance in comparison with three prior conferences. 

A meeting of a subgroup of conference organizers, attendees, and presenters was held January 9 -10, 2020 to reflect on the impact of the conference and contribute to developing an impact summary report. There were 17 attendees at this meeting who learned how conference organizers create inclusive and safe environments with diverse scholars who are integrating the arts, humanities, and sciences in various and successful ways. 

Key Outcomes of the Project include

Broadening participation

  • Seeking out, inviting, and financially supporting early-career scholars from underrepresented groups to participate in and present at the conference

  • Seeding innovative collaborations across, sciences, arts, and humanities with leaders who locate themselves in the STEM, diversity, and inclusion in higher education and the STEM/STEAM professions.

  • Doubling the size and increasing reach of the conference

Intellectual Merit

  • Sharing and learning performance-based educational and science research practices

  • Providing organizing committee volunteers and conference presenters with opportunities to develop skills in mentoring, building inclusive environments, and communicating science

  • Creating more access to the scholarly work of conference attendees, presenters, and volunteers by creating a website, social media plan, and publishing conference video content

  • Rebranding the CESTEMER conference as Cultivating Ensembles to create more accessible social media and public relations presence. 

  • Creating an ongoing virtual Coffee Chat community conversation series in response to COVID-19 pandemic limiting gatherings featuring topics Building Community in Virtual Environments and STEAM as Scientific Revolution. The virtual meetings increase the visibility of conference presenters and the conference mission. 

The Cultivating Ensembles Organizing Committee and subcommittees are planning virtual Coffee Chat events for 2021 and hopefully the resumption of the face-to-face conference in 2022. Efforts to recruit volunteers for our Organizing Committee are ongoing. We are updating our website  www.cultivatingensembles.org and social media accounts with ongoing event and conference-related information.

WHY do people attend?

  • Nurture inclusive and collaborative STEM/STEAM cultures
  • Build relationships that redefine traditional boundaries
  • Acknowledge and use the human lens to understand how we make, practice, and communicate science and research. 

WHO attends and presents at the conference?

Educators, researchers, performers, artists, students, activists, advocates and entrepreneurs from diverse areas   academia, the arts, community organizations, business, industry, and nonprofits are all welcome in Cultivating Ensembles. We come together to transform the human/cultural experience of professional and social identities in STEM/STEAM. 

HOW we work to create diverse and inclusive events.

Participants co-create playful, interactive, collaborative formats in order for practitioners and scholars to explore and share the ways that they build and advance science and research. Organized by a combination of previous organizers, recent attendees and new associates, each conference is unique. The format is highly interactive. In addition to invited speakers, there are hands-on sessions, open spaces, and a share fair.

To volunteer or find out more information please contact us at info@cultivatingensembles.org
